Mekedatu means 'goat's leap in Kannada.A lot of tourists visit this place, a high number of people drown in the river, either when swimming or slipping off the cliff. It is a very dangerous place.
list.additionalInformation: This is an excellent location to visit for a day, near Bangalore. The Cauvery river passes by a very narrow ravine, cutting through the rocks for ages and ages. This gives the place a very unique landscape. The rocks, cut by the flowing river for time immemorial ,makes this place interesting.
list.nearByPlaces: Chunchi Falls

list.name: Hebbe
list.description: Hebbe Falls is situated about 10 km away from the famous hill station Kemmangundi. This waterfalls are inside a coffee estate and can be reached either by walk or four-wheeler. Hebbe Falls gushes down from a height of 551 ft in two stages to form Dodda Hebbe (Big Falls) and Chikka Hebbe (Small Falls.)
list.additionalInformation: Kemmangundi hill station is said to be the summer retreat for the erstwhile Wodeyar ruler, Krishnaraja Wodeyar IV. It has beautifully laid gardens, magnificent mountain ranges and splendid valleys, and is an excellent visual treat for the tourists. One can take 8 kms trek to reach the Hebbe falls.
list.nearByPlaces: Annapoorneshwari Temple,Sringeri Temple,Mullayanagiri Trek,Kudremukh Trek,Kuringal Gudda,Bhadra Dam,Chikkamagaluru Hillstation,Kemmanagundi Hillstation,Gangamoola Hillstation,Jhari Falls,Kalasa Temple

list.name: Gokak
list.description: The Gokak Falls is a waterfall located on the Ghataprabha River. After a long winding course, the Ghataprabha river takes a leap of 52 metres (171 ft) over the sand-stone cliff amidst a picturesque gorge of the rued valley, resembling Niagara Falls on a smaller scale. The waterfall is horse shoe shaped at the crest, with a flood breadth of 177 metres.
list.additionalInformation: Gokak is surrounded on one side by a range of hills, and on the other side by a vast plain of black soil. Since the colonial era, the hydroelectric station under the waterfall has been used to power Gokak Mills, one of the largest manufacturers and exporters of yarn in India. The river Markandeya, a tributary of the Ghataprabha, dashes down through 43ft step wise hill plates to form Goduchinamalaki Falls.
list.nearByPlaces: Godchinamalaki Falls,Jamboti Falls,Saundatti Yellamma

list.name: Abbey
list.description: The falls was earlier called Jessi falls named after a British officer's wife. However, the place was a thick jungle area back then. Years later, the beautiful waterfall was discovered by Mr. Neravanda B.Nanaiah who bought the place from the government and converted it into a coffee and spices plantation that is surrounding the waterfall today.
list.additionalInformation: One of the most amazing attractions in coorg, the picturesque view of the fall will suerly take your breath away and also provide you with few kodak moments. You will also find a hanging bridge from which an exceptional view of this waterfall is mesmerising.
list.nearByPlaces: Talacauvery Temple,Kumaraparvatha Trek,Tadiandamol Trek,Harangi Dam,Coorg Hillstation,Irpu Falls

list.name: Dudhsagar
list.description: Dudhsagar Falls (literally Sea of Milk ) is a four-tiered waterfall located on the Mandovi River in the border of the Indian states of Karnataka and Goa. It is 60 km from Panaji by road and is located on the Madgaon-Belgaum rail route about 46 km east of Madgaon and 80 km south of Belgaum.
list.additionalInformation: Dudhsagar Falls is amongst India's tallest waterfalls with a height of 310m (1017ft) and an average width of 30m (100ft).

list.name: Barkana
list.description: Barkana Falls is one of the ten highest waterfalls in India.
list.additionalInformation: The waterfall is located in Balehalli forest area, at a distance of about 7km from the Agumbe village in Shimoga district of Karnataka. The waterfall has a height of about 850ft. It is located at a height of about 259m above sea level. It originates from the Seeta River that flows through this region.
list.nearByPlaces: Sigandur Chowdeshwari,Kodachadri Trek,Narasimha Parvatha,Kavaledurga Fort,Linganamakki Dam,Agumbe Hillstation,Kundadri Hillstation,Kodachadri Temple,Jog Falls,Kunchikal Falls

list.name: Kunchikal
list.description: Kunchikal Falls, also called Kunchikal Abbe, is located near Masthikatte-Hulikal bordering Udupi-Shimoga districts of state of Karnataka. Kunchikal falls is formed by Varahi river.
list.additionalInformation: The specialty of this waterfall is that hundreds of rocks form the backdrop against which the water cascades down and presents a marvellous view. The waterfall has a height of around 455m (1,493ft).
list.nearByPlaces: Sigandur Chowdeshwari,Kodachadri Trek,Narasimha Parvatha,Kavaledurga Fort,Linganamakki Dam,Agumbe Hillstation,Kundadri Hillstation,Kodachadri Temple,Jog Falls,Barkana Falls

list.name: Chunchi
list.description: It is 80 kms from Bangalore on the way to mekedatu. With own vehicle these places are ideal outing spots.
list.additionalInformation: About 16kms before 'Sangama' you have to take a left turn to the Yeleguri village to go to this waterfall. The waterfall is about 6km away from the deviation.
list.nearByPlaces: Mekedatu Falls

list.name: Apsarakonda
list.description: Apsarakonda Falls is a perfect destination to break free from the monotony of routine life. Set in a small village named Apsarakonda in Honnavar taluk of Uttara Kannada district of Karnataka the waterfall possesses enthralling beauty. The scenic location of the waterfall is situated near the Western coast of Karnataka and has a pristine beach in its vicinity apart from a tall hill and a lovely pond. All these elements of nature are enough to mesmerize anyone visiting the place.
list.additionalInformation: A unique fact about the waterfall is that the water flows down through the roots of a peepal (sacred fig) tree while descending to the pond below. There are natural caves hidden from plain sight by the old tree
list.nearByPlaces: Dandeli Trek,Supa Dam,Yana Hillstation,Murudeshwara Temple,Gokarna Beach,Devbagh Beach,Netrani Beach,OM Beach,Magod Falls,Unchalli Falls,Sathodi Falls

list.name: Jhari
list.description: Located near Mullayanagiri this waterfall is ideal to visit after trekking to Mullayanagiri. One can reach the falls by either trek route or use jeep services from main road. The trek route takes you through the coffee plantations and gives you a whole new experience of the beauty of nature. The 15-20 minutes drive up the falls also gives a good experience. Water falls with great force and is very cold which gives you a chilling experience. Best to plan Mullayangiri, Jhari waterfall and Bababudangiri in same day visit.
list.additionalInformation: One can stay at Jhari eco resort. They also arrange a jungle trek along  a warm stream. Best to plan with Mullayanagiri and Bababudangiri.
list.nearByPlaces: Annapoorneshwari Temple,Sringeri Temple,Mullayanagiri Trek,Kudremukh Trek,Kuringal Gudda,Bhadra Dam,Chikkamagaluru Hillstation,Kemmanagundi Hillstation,Gangamoola Hillstation,Hebbe Falls,Kalasa Temple

list.name: Irpu
list.description: The Irupu Falls are located in the Brahmagiri Range in the Kodagu district of Karnataka, India, bordering the Wayanad district of Kerala. The Falls are also known as the Lakshmana Tirtha Falls,derived from the name of the tributary of Cauvery which starts from these falls, the Lakshmana Tirtha River. One needs to walk inside the Brahmagiri sanctuary to reach this place. You have lot of flora and fauna to enjoy the walk and beautiful varieties off butterflies which makes your day before you reach the fall for a soothing bath inside.
list.bestSeason: Monsoon. Mornings would be the best time to visit the falls.
list.additionalInformation: According to popular legend, Rama and Lakshmana, passed along the Bhramagiri range whilst searching for Rama's beloved, Sita. When Rama asked Lakshmana to fetch him drinking water, Lakshmana shot an arrow into the Brahmagiri hills and brought into being the river Lakshmana Tirtha. Due to this legend, the Falls is believed to possess the power to cleanse sins and is visited by thousands of devotees on Shivaratri day.
list.nearByPlaces: Talacauvery Temple,Kumaraparvatha Trek,Tadiandamol Trek,Harangi Dam,Coorg Hillstation,Abbey Falls

list.name: Magod
list.description: Magod falls is 18KM away from Yellapura city center. The river Bedti falls from a height of nearly 200m in two steps. One has to get ticket from forest check post and can visit this place. Magod falls is a scenic beauty, which asks for a small walk to the peak of the mountain from where this falls can be enjoyed. Cant get into the waters anywhere as one has to watch the falls from watch tower located almost 600 meters away from the falls but the falls is very clearly visible.There are 3 levels of viewing points to see this Magod falls.
list.bestSeason: Monsoon. The waterfall is usually covered with fog during Monsoon. The waterfall does not seem to be interesting during other seasons. It gets less visitors during December during which you can enjoy the sight with less crowd.
list.additionalInformation: No facilities are available near the falls. Carry lot of water especially if you are visiting the falls in summer or post monsoon as this small walk sometimes could be tiering. It is a bit crowded place as well
list.nearByPlaces: Dandeli Trek,Supa Dam,Yana Hillstation,Murudeshwara Temple,Gokarna Beach,Devbagh Beach,Netrani Beach,OM Beach,Apsarakonda Falls,Unchalli Falls,Sathodi Falls

list.name: Unchalli
list.description:
Unchalli Falls Kannada: ಉಂಚಳ್ಳಿ ಜಲಪಾತ, also known as Lushington Falls, is a waterfall created by a 116 metres (381 ft) drop in the Aghanashini river. The fall is located near Siddapur in Uttara Kannada District of Karnataka, India. The falls are named for J. D. Lushington, a District Collector for the British Government, who discovered the falls in 1845.
Heggarne,
a hamlet in Uttara Kannada district,
is 35 km from Siddapur.The falls are reached by a 5 kilometres(3.1 mi) trek from Heggarne through thick forest.Here the river makes a cavalcade of water falls and eventually leaps into a steep valley to form a spectacular,
picturesque waterfall.The falls are sometimes called Keppa Joga because of the deafening sound they make.

The vertical mountain slopes and pathway,
profound chilly breeze plus the astonishing plants,
flowers and vegetation keep the viewers dumb
while trekking until the point of roaring Unchalli Falls storming down the earth.
list.additionalInformation: The special feature of this region is that even during lean rainy season there will be plenty of rain to maintaining its natural beauty of pouring water from the heights to keep us always happy.Unchalli falls can be visited at any time of the year as it offers an excellent view of the surrounding flora.
list.nearByPlaces: Dandeli Trek,Supa Dam,Yana Hillstation,Murudeshwara Temple,Gokarna Beach,Devbagh Beach,Netrani Beach,OM Beach,Apsarakonda Falls,Magod Falls,Sathodi Falls

list.name: Sathodi
list.description: Sathodi Falls is a waterfall in India that is formed by several unnamed streams near Kallaramarane Ghat, Uttara Kannada District, near Sirsi, and 32 km from Yellapur. It is about 15 metres (49.2 feet) tall. The stream then flows into the backwaters of the Kodasalli Dam, into the Kali River. This is popularly known as the Mini Niagara. This falls forms a part of the Ganeshgudi forest range.
list.additionalInformation: The waterfall is a beauty for photography. Not advisable for senior citizen as one has to walk a lot to reach the waterfall. It offers it's visitors to stand right under the falls and enjoy it's beauty.
list.nearByPlaces: Dandeli Trek,Supa Dam,Yana Hillstation,Murudeshwara Temple,Gokarna Beach,Devbagh Beach,Netrani Beach,OM Beach,Apsarakonda Falls,Magod Falls,Unchalli Falls

list.name: Chunchankatte
list.description: Cauvery flows into Chunchankatte roaring thunderously forming a 60 feet height and approximately 300 to 400 feet wide waterfalls. This place is situated 57 km from Mysore in Krishna Raja Nagar (K.R.Nagar) taluk, Mysore district. When the river reaches to cascade it is divided into two separate falls and joins again to continue to flow as one into Krishna Raja Sagar (KRS) dam. The roar is deafening and the spray from the falls is refreshing. The gushing of water from every nook and corner of the rocky bed forms a milky white falls and the brown colored water in some parts of the falls shows the fertility that Cauvery brings along with her to the deccan plateau. At one angle you can see a large quantity of water whoosh to about 10 feet away from the jutting rocky bed before cascading into the river displaying the force at which it flows.
list.additionalInformation: The water force is well tapped here and there is a hydraulic power generating station installed. It is in its best form during monsoon, but during seasons where there is less inflow of water, you can climb onto the rocks and explore more.
list.nearByPlaces: Chamundeshwari Temple,Venugopalaswami Temple,KRS Dam,GRS fantasy park,Mysuru Palace

list.name: Godchinamalaki
list.description:
The Godachinmalki Falls is a waterfall located on Markandeya river in Belgaum district, Gokak Taluk, Karnataka, India. It is 15 kilometers away from Gokak and 40 kilometers from Belgaum. It is located in a deep green valley.
Godachinmalki falls is also known as Markandeya falls
list.additionalInformation:
There are actually two falls formed here. The Markandeya river takes a first fall from a height of about 25 metres and flows into a rocky valley. After a short distance from the rocky valley, it takes the second fall from a height of about 20 metres.
Within 10 km distance Gokak falls is located from Godachinamalki vai Melmanahatti & Maradimath.Later Markandeya river joins Ghataprabha river near Gokak.
list.nearByPlaces: Gokak Falls,Jamboti Falls,Saundatti Yellamma

list.name: Jamboti
list.description: Vajrapoha(Jamboti), is a breathtaking falls in Khanapur taluk of Belgaum dist.One can view the falls by trekking onto the top, or by front. Viewing the falls from the top is a more difficult trek than viewing from front. With the permission from the forest department camping can be done on the trek route to the top.
list.additionalInformation: Formed by Mandovi River.
list.nearByPlaces: Gokak Falls,Godchinamalaki Falls,Saundatti Yellamma

list.name: Bandaje
list.description: Bandaje falls is formed by a tributary of Netravathi river and is located in a remote area of western ghats, which can be reached through trekking with the help of guides. Height of waterfalls is about 200 feet. The path to Bandaje falls from Valambra goes through thick ever green forest which ends in grass lands and those who trek without guide are likely to be lost in forest.Locally this falls is called as Bandaje Arbi, where Arbi means falls in Tulu language. Permission from Belthangady wildlife range office, Kudremukh national park is required to trek to Bandaje falls.
list.additionalInformation: To visit Bandaje Falls, there are two different routes. If you are travelling via Mangalore - Ujire, it is located 25 km from Ujire. Travel 6 km from Ujire towards Charmadi Ghat, take left at Somanthadka, travel for another 6 km, then take a right turn, and travel for 2 km to find a village named kadirudyavara, from where you can have the remote view of the Falls. However, you have to trek for 10 more km from Kadirudyavara to reach the falls
list.nearByPlaces: Dharmasthala Manjunatha,Kukke Subramanya,Kumaraparvatha Trek

list.name: Kumaraparvatha
list.description: The Pushpagiri or Subramanya Hills (also referred as Kumaraparvatha) is the second-highest peak of Kodagu, and sixth highest peak in Karnataka
list.additionalInformation: Trekking starting point is Kukke Subramanya.Considered among the toughest treks in South India, It is a perfect mix of physical challenge and natural beauty of the Pushpagiri Wildlife sanctuary.The weather at Kumara Parvata is volatile and can change drastically on short notice.Get down at subramanya and get fresh at the public toilets on the main street of Subramanya temple.Have early breakfast from the shops in the same street and also pack some lunch if you do not want to pay at Bhatru mane.Reach forest department office, pay the forest entry charges and leave behind your camping gears to Kumara Parvatha trek (remember camping is not allowed at the peak)
list.nearByPlaces: Dharmasthala Manjunatha,Kukke Subramanya,Bandaje Falls

list.name: Ombattu Gudda
list.description: Ombattu Gudda, one of the highest peaks of the Western Range is located along the borderline of Chikmagalur and Hassan. The entire to and fro trekking activity of the peak -which derives its name from the Kannada word ‘ombattu’ (meaning 9) and ‘gudda’ (meaning hills) due to its location and appearance - would cover around 18km over two days.
list.additionalInformation: Trek length-24 kms (8 hours up te hill and 2 hours down the hill),Trek difficulty level- Difficult,Height: 3236 feet,Get fresh at Gundya forest checkpost,Camping site: Grasslands on the way,Permission: Difficult to take.

list.name: Mysuru Palace
list.description:
Architecture:  style of the palace is commonly described as Indo-Saracenic, and blends together Hindu, Muslim, Rajput, and Gothic styles of architecture. It is a three-storied stone structure, with marble domes and a 145 ft five-storied tower. The palace is surrounded by a large garden.
 Special events : Every autumn, the Palace is the venue for the famous Mysuru Dasara festival, during which leading artists perform on a stage set up in the palace grounds. On the tenth day of the festival Vijaya Dashami, a parade with caparisoned elephants and other floats originate from the palace grounds. The Dasara festival is celebrated in the months of September and October of each year. This festival has been celebrated by the Wadiyars at Srirangapatna from 1610 and in Mysuru with great pomp from 1799 and the tradition still is carried on although the scale of the celebrations has diminished. The Dasara festivities have become an integral part of the culture and life in Mysuru. To celebrate this festival the Palace of Mysuru is illuminated with more than 96,000 lights during that two month period.

Unique rooms: 
1) Public Durbar Hall
2) Private Durbar or Ambavilasa Palace
3) Gombe Thotti (Doll’s Pavilion)
4) Kalyana Mantapa
5) Portrait Gallery
list.bestSeason:
Palace Timings 10:00am till 5:30pm
Adults Rs. 40
Children below 10 years : Free Entrance
Children between 10 - 18 Years : Rs. 20
Educational Tour : (Letter from School Management) Rs. 10
Foreigners : Rs. 200

 PALACE LIGHTINGS ON SUNDAYS AND PUBLIC HOLIDAYS FROM 7:00pm till 7:30pm
list.additionalInformation:
Construction started: 1897
Completed: 1912
Owner: Rajmata Pramoda Devi Wadiyar
The palace complex includes twelve Hindu temples. The oldest was built in the 14th century, while the most recent was built in 1953.
1) Someshvara Temple, dedicated to God Lord Shiva
2) Lakshmiramana Temple, dedicated to God Lord Vishnu
3) Shwetha Varahaswamy Temple, dedicated to Lord Varahaswamy
4) Sri Prasanna krishna Swami Temple
5) Sri Bhuvaneshwari Temple
6) Kodi Someshwaraswami Temple
7) Sri Gayatri Temple
8) Sri Trineshwara temple

list.name: Kalasa
list.description:
Kalasa is a holy temple-town located in Chikkamagaluru district in Karnataka. Kalasa is located on the banks of the Bhadra River. Kalasa is also known for the sacred Pancha Theertha, which stands for five sacred waters. They are:
1)Vasishta Theertha—This Theertha is special because of the Sage Vasishta
2)Naga Theertha—This one is special as it is believed that a dip here will cure Naga Dosha.
3)Koti Theertha—Koti Devatha remained here at the request of Sage Agasthya during Girija Kalyana
4)Rudra Theertha—It is believed that offering pinda here is as auspicious as offering pinda at Vishnu Pada or Gaya
5)Amba Theertha— The sacred water spot of Goddess Parvati
6)Duggapan Katte—From this spot, the whole town of Kalasa can be seen.
list.additionalInformation:
Phone: 082632 74705

Festivals: 
1)Girija Kalyana – This is the celebration of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati.
2)Kalasa Car Festival – This the Rathotsava of the Kalaseshwara Temple
3)Venkataramana Swamy Temple Car Festival—This is the Rathotsava of the Venkataramana Swamy Temple

list.name: Skandagiri
list.description: Also known as Kalavara Durga, Skandagiri is located around 70km from Bangalore and can be reached within 2 hours of drive from the city. Offering panoramic views of the night sky and the sunrise, this 8km trek comprises of ascending and descending through rugged terrains and can be completed within 4-5 hours of ascending and descending.
list.additionalInformation: Till the Papagni Temple, the climb offers moderate challenges to the trekkers. Hereafter, it gets considerably challenging as the walls of the ancient temple offers various challenges to the trekkers. Overcoming these challenges, reach to the peak by 2am. Post this, relax around a pleasant bonfire that also will keep you warm and laze within the individually provided sleeping bags. With the advent of the morning at around 5am, witness the panoramic views of the sunrise and start descending down the hill.
list.nearByPlaces: Nandi Hills

list.name: Hampi
list.description: Hampi (Hampe) is a village and temple town recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, listed as the Group of Monuments at Hampi in northern Karnataka, India. It was one of the richest and largest cities in the world during its prime. It is located within the ruins of the city of Vijayanagara, the former capital of the Vijayanagara Empire. Predating the city of Vijayanagara, Hampi continues to be an important religious centre, housing the Virupaksha Temple and several other monuments belonging to the old city.
list.additionalInformation: Hampi is situated on the banks of the Tungabhadra River. It is 353 km from Bangalore and 74 km from Bellary. The annual Hampi Utsav or Vijaya Festival has been celebrated since the reign of Vijayanagara. It is organized by the Government of Karnataka as Nada Festival.
list.nearByPlaces: Virupaksha Temple,Tungabhadra Dam,Daroji Bear Sanctuary,Bellary Fort,Anjanadri Temple,Navabrindavan Temple,Huligemma Devi Temple,Kishkinda waterpark

list.name: Huligemma Devi
list.description: Vyaghrapuri is a Sanskrit Name of holy pilgrimage centre Huligi. Huligi is an abode of Godess Durga. This is a self manifested temple of her, located on the scenic Tungabhadra River. She has manifested herself in form of an abstract rock. This temple is situated in a village called Huligi.
list.additionalInformation: It is located around 20 Kilometers away from the district Head quarters Koppala.
list.nearByPlaces: Virupaksha Temple,Tungabhadra Dam,Daroji Bear Sanctuary,Bellary Fort,Anjanadri Temple,Navabrindavan Temple,Hampi Heritage,Kishkinda waterpark

list.name: Daroji Bear Sanctuary
list.description: Daroji Sloth Bear Sanctuary is located in Ballari district in Karnataka. The sanctuary was created exclusively for the preservation of Indian Sloth Bear. It is about 50 km from Bellary and about 15 km from the World heritage site Hampi.
list.additionalInformation:
The sanctuary is open between 4 PM to 6 PM on all days. There is a watch tower within the sanctuary, opposite Karadikallu Gudda, that provides a vantage point to view the bears descending from the adjacent hillocks during evening hours. 
Entry fee is 50Rs per person. 
Phone: 080 3017 8146
list.nearByPlaces: Virupaksha Temple,Tungabhadra Dam,Huligemma Temple,Bellary Fort,Anjanadri Temple,Navabrindavan Temple,Huligemma Devi Temple,Kishkinda waterpark

list.name: Bellary Fort
list.description: The Bellary Fort was built on top of a hill called the Ballari Gudda or the Fort Hill. It was built in two parts namely, the Upper Fort and the Lower Fort. The Upper Fort was built by Hanumappa Nayaka, a feudatory of Vijayanagara Empire, but the Lower Fort was built by Hyder Ali in later part of the 18th century.
list.additionalInformation: The entrance for each person is 5Rs. Closing time will be 5:30 pm better be down the mountain before.

list.name: Tonse hanging bridge
list.description: Tonse is a combined village, which include Tonse West and Tonse East situated about 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) from Udupi on the western coast of South India, between the Arabian Sea and Western Ghats. Just three miles off the seacoast are the St. Mary’s Islands, a tourist spot, (locally known as ‘Tonse-Par’ meaning, ‘beyond Tonse’), reachable from the port town of Malpe, by powerboat or country craft. In the delta of Suvarna, a group of about a dozen islands, covered with lush green coconut palms surrounded by clear blue waters adds to the natural beauty to the village. An impressive looking hanging bridge, which attracts curious visitors from far and wide connects one of the better-known islands, Thimmankudru to the mainland. House Boats are in the backwaters of Hoode.
list.additionalInformation: Tonse is bounded on its western side the Arabian Sea while on the eastern side the Suvarna river runs, creating a number of islands in its delta before it finally merges with the sea at Kodibengre. The Hanging Bridge was constructed by 2 Karnataka Engineer NCC and the Bridge was named as Deepak in memory of a late NCC Cadet. The complete material for construction of this bridge was made available by local people from their own private funds.
list.nearByPlaces: Kollur Mookambika,Malpe Beach,Maravanthe Beach,Hattiangadi Temple

list.name: Cubbon Park
list.description: Cubbon Park is a landmark 'lung' area of the Bengaluru city, located within the heart of city in the Central Administrative Area. Originally created in 1870, when Major General Richard Sankey was the then British Chief Engineer of Mysore state, it covered an area of 100 acres (0.40 km2) and subsequent expansion has taken place and the area reported now is about 300 acres (1.2 km). It has a rich recorded history of abundant flora and fauna plantations coupled with numerous impressive and aesthetically located buildings and statues of famous personages, in its precincts.
list.additionalInformation: This public park was first named as Meade’s Park after Sir John Meade, the acting Commissioner of Mysuru in 1870 and subsequently renamed as Cubbon Park after the longest serving commissioner of the time, Sir Mark Cubbon. To commemorate the Silver Jubilee of Sri Krishnaraja Wodeyar’s rule in Mysore State, in 1927, the park was again renamed as Sri. Chamarajendra Park, in memory of the 19th-century ruler of the state Sri Chamarajendra Wodeyar (1868–94), during whose rule the park came into existence.The landscaping in the park creatively integrates natural rock outcrops with thickets of trees, massive bamboos, with grassy expanse and flowerbeds and the monuments within its limits, regulated by the Horticulture Department of the Government of Karnataka. The predominantly green area of the park has many motorable roads, and the well-laid-out walking paths running through the park are frequented by early morning walkers and the naturalists who study plants in the tranquil natural environment.
list.nearByPlaces: Iskcon Temple,Nandi Hills,Wonder La,Nijagal Betta,Hutridurga Trek
